summary.para: Represents a Unicode character.

threadSafety.para: This type is safe for multithreaded operations.

content.para: The .NET Framework uses the T:System.Char structure to represent Unicode characters. The Unicode Standard identifies each Unicode character with a unique 21-bit scalar number called a code point, and defines the UTF-16 encoding form that specifies how a code point is encoded into a sequence of one or more 16-bit values. Each 16-bit value ranges from hexadecimal 0x0000 through 0xFFFF and is stored in a T:System.Char structure. The value of a T:System.Char object is its 16-bit numeric (ordinal) value.

A T:System.String object is a sequential collection of T:System.Char structures that represents a string of text. Most Unicode characters can be represented by a single T:System.Char object, but a character that is encoded as a base character, surrogate pair, and/or combining character sequence is represented by multiple T:System.Char objects. For this reason, a T:System.Char structure in a T:System.String object is not necessarily equivalent to a single Unicode character.
For more information about the Unicode Standard, see the Unicode home pagehttp://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=37123.

The T:System.Char structure provides methods to compare T:System.Char objects, convert the value of the current T:System.Char object to an object of another type, and determine the Unicode category of a T:System.Char object:

listItem.para: Use the Overload:System.Char.CompareTo and Overload:System.Char.Equals methods to compare T:System.Char objects.

Use the M:System.Char.ConvertFromUtf32(System.Int32) method to convert a code point to a string. Use the Overload:System.Char.ConvertToUtf32 methods to convert a T:System.Char object or a surrogate pair of T:System.Char objects to a code point.

Use the Overload:System.Char.GetUnicodeCategory methods to get the Unicode category of a character. Use the Overload:System.Char.IsControl, Overload:System.Char.IsDigit, Overload:System.Char.IsHighSurrogate, Overload:System.Char.IsLetter, Overload:System.Char.IsLetterOrDigit, Overload:System.Char.IsLower, Overload:System.Char.IsLowSurrogate, Overload:System.Char.IsNumber, Overload:System.Char.IsPunctuation, Overload:System.Char.IsSeparator, Overload:System.Char.IsSurrogate, Overload:System.Char.IsSurrogatePair, Overload:System.Char.IsSymbol, Overload:System.Char.IsUpper, and Overload:System.Char.IsWhiteSpace methods to determine whether a character is in a particular Unicode category such as digit, letter, punctuation, control character, and so on.

Use the Overload:System.Char.GetNumericValue methods to convert a T:System.Char object that represents a number to a numeric value type. Use M:System.Char.Parse(System.String) and M:System.Char.TryParse(System.String,System.Char@) to convert a character in a string into a T:System.Char object. Use Overload:System.Char.ToString to convert a T:System.Char object to a T:System.String object.

Use the Overload:System.Char.ToLower, M:System.Char.ToLowerInvariant(System.Char), Overload:System.Char.ToUpper, and M:System.Char.ToUpperInvariant(System.Char) methods to change the case of a T:System.Char object.

content.para: This type implements the T:System.IConvertible, T:System.IComparable, and T:System.IComparable`1 interfaces. Use the T:System.Convert class for conversions instead of this type's explicit interface member implementation of T:System.IConvertible.
The following code example demonstrates some of the methods in T:System.Char.

summary.para: Compares this instance to a specified object or value type, and returns an indication of their relative values.
Compares this instance to a specified T:System.Char object and returns an indication of their relative values.

content.para: A T:System.Char object to compare.

returnValue.para: A signed number indicating the relative values of this instance and the value parameter.

entry.para: This instance is less than value.
This instance is equal to value.
This instance is greater than value.

content.para: This method implements the T:System.IComparable`1 interface and performs slightly better than the M:System.Char.CompareTo(System.Object) method because it does not have to convert the value parameter to an object.
The comparison performed by this method is based on the encoded values of this instance and value, not their lexicographical characteristics.

If the M:System.Char.CompareTo(System.Object) method parameter type has fewer bits (is narrower) than the instance type, some programming languages perform an implicit widening conversion that transforms the value of the parameter into a value with more bits.

For example, suppose the instance type is T:System.Int32 and the parameter type is T:System.Byte. The Microsoft C# compiler generates instructions to represent the value of the parameter as an T:System.Int32 object, then generates a M:System.Int32.CompareTo(System.Object) method that compares the values of the T:System.Int32 instance and the T:System.Int32 parameter representation.

Typically, implicit widening conversions are performed on numeric types. Consult your programming language's documentation to determine if its compiler performs widening conversions. If the instance and parameter types mismatch and a suitable conversion is not available, the compiler generates instructions to box the parameter and invoke the M:System.Char.CompareTo(System.Object) overload that takes an T:System.Object parameter.
The following code example demonstrates generic and non-generic versions of the CompareTo method for several value and reference types.

summary.para: Compares this instance to a specified object or value type, and returns an indication of their relative values.
Compares this instance to a specified object and returns an indication of their relative values.

content.para: An object to compare this instance to, or null.

returnValue.para: A signed number indicating the relative values of this instance and the value parameter.

entry.para: This instance is less than value.
This instance is equal to value.
This instance is greater than value.

content.para: value is not a T:System.Char object.
The M:System.Char.CompareTo(System.Object) method implements the T:System.IComparable interface.
The value parameter must be null or an instance of T:System.Char; otherwise, an exception is thrown.

The comparison performed by this method is based on the encoded values of this instance and value, not necessarily their lexicographical characteristics. Any instance of T:System.Char, regardless of its value, is considered greater than null.
The following code example demonstrates M:System.Char.CompareTo(System.Object).

summary.para: Converts the specified Unicode code point into a UTF-16 encoded string.

content.para: A 21-bit Unicode code point.

returnValue.para: A string consisting of one T:System.Char object or a surrogate pair of T:System.Char objects equivalent to the code point specified by the utf32 parameter.

content.para: utf32 is not a valid 21-bit Unicode code point ranging from U+0 through U+10FFFF, excluding the surrogate pair range from U+D800 through U+DFFF.

Use this method to convert a 21-bit Unicode code point to a UTF-16 encoded string before testing the string with methods such as M:System.Char.IsLowSurrogate(System.Char) and M:System.Char.IsHighSurrogate(System.Char).

A valid code point outside the Basic Multilingual Plane (BMP) always yields a valid surrogate pair. However, a valid code point within the BMP might not yield a valid result according to the Unicode standard because no linguistic processing is used in the conversion. For that reason, use the T:System.Text.UTF32Encoding class to convert bulk UTF-32 data into bulk UTF-16 data.
The following code example demonstrates the M:System.Char.ConvertToUtf32(System.Char,System.Char) and M:System.Char.ConvertFromUtf32(System.Int32) methods.

summary.para: Converts the value of a UTF-16 encoded surrogate pair into a Unicode code point.
Converts the value of a UTF-16 encoded surrogate pair into a Unicode code point.

content.para: A high surrogate character (that is, a code point ranging from U+D800 through U+DBFF).
A low surrogate character (that is, a code point ranging from U+DC00 through U+DFFF).

returnValue.para: The 21-bit Unicode code point represented by the highSurrogate and lowSurrogate parameters.

content.para: highSurrogate is not in the range U+D800 through U+DBFF, or lowSurrogate is not in the range U+DC00 through U+DFFF.
Use this method to convert a surrogate pair into a 21-bit Unicode code point. To convert UTF-16 data into UTF-32 data, use the T:System.Text.UTF32Encoding class.
The following code example demonstrates the M:System.Char.ConvertToUtf32(System.Char,System.Char) and M:System.Char.ConvertFromUtf32(System.Int32) methods.

summary.para: Converts the value of a UTF-16 encoded surrogate pair into a Unicode code point.
Converts the value of a UTF-16 encoded character or surrogate pair at a specified position in a string into a Unicode code point.

content.para: A string that contains a character or surrogate pair.
The index position of the character or surrogate pair in s.

returnValue.para: The 21-bit Unicode code point represented by the character or surrogate pair at the position in the s parameter specified by the index parameter.

content.para: s is null.
index is not a position within s.
The specified index position contains a surrogate pair, and either the first character in the pair is not a valid high surrogate or the second character in the pair is not a valid low surrogate.
Use this method to convert a character or surrogate pair into a 21-bit Unicode code point. To convert UTF-16 data into UTF-32 data, use the T:System.Text.UTF32Encoding class.
The following code example demonstrates the M:System.Char.ConvertToUtf32(System.Char,System.Char) and M:System.Char.ConvertFromUtf32(System.Int32) methods.

summary.para: Returns a value indicating whether this instance is equal to the specified T:System.Char object.

content.para: A T:System.Char object to compare to this instance.

returnValue.para: true if the value parameter equals the value of this instance; otherwise, false.

content.para: This method implements the T:System.IEquatable`1 interface, and performs slightly better than M:System.Char.Equals(System.Object) because it does not need to unbox the obj parameter.

summary.para: Returns a value indicating whether this instance is equal to a specified object.

content.para: An object to compare with this instance or null.

returnValue.para: true if obj is an instance of T:System.Char and equals the value of this instance; otherwise, false.

content.para: The comparison performed by this method is based on the encoded values of this instance and obj, not necessarily their lexicographical characteristics.
The following code example demonstrates M:System.Char.Equals(System.Object).

summary.para: Returns the hash code for this instance.

returnValue.para: A 32-bit signed integer hash code.

summary.para: Converts a specified numeric Unicode character to a double-precision floating point number.
Converts the specified numeric Unicode character to a double-precision floating point number.

content.para: A Unicode character.

returnValue.para: The numeric value of c if that character represents a number; otherwise, -1.0.

content.para: For example, if c is '5', the return value is 5. However, if c is 'z', the return value is -1.0.

A character has an associated numeric value if and only if it is a member of one of the following categories in T:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory: DecimalDigitNumber, LetterNumber, or OtherNumber.
The following code example demonstrates M:System.Char.GetNumericValue(System.Char).

summary.para: Converts a specified numeric Unicode character to a double-precision floating point number.
Converts the numeric Unicode character at the specified position in a specified string to a double-precision floating point number.

content.para: A T:System.String.
The character position in s.

returnValue.para: The numeric value of the character at position index in s if that character represents a number; otherwise, -1.

content.para: s is null.
index is less than zero or greater than the last position in s.
For example, if the character at position index in s is '5', the return value is 5. However, if the character at position index in s is 'z', the return value is -1.
Character positions in a string are indexed starting from zero.

A character has an associated numeric value if and only if it is a member of one of the following categories in T:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory: DecimalDigitNumber, LetterNumber, or OtherNumber.
The following code example demonstrates M:System.Char.GetNumericValue(System.Char).

summary.para: Returns the T:System.TypeCode for value type T:System.Char.

returnValue.para: The enumerated constant, F:System.TypeCode.Char.

summary.para: Categorizes a Unicode character into a group identified by one of the T:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory values.
Categorizes a specified Unicode character into a group identified by one of the T:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory values.

content.para: A Unicode character.

returnValue.para: A T:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory value that identifies the group that contains c.

content.para: The following code example demonstrates M:System.Char.GetUnicodeCategory(System.Char).

Categorizes the character at the specified position in a specified string into a group identified by one of the T:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory values.

content.para: A T:System.String.
The character position in s.

returnValue.para: A T:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory enumerated constant that identifies the group that contains the character at position index in s.

content.para: s is null.
index is less than zero or greater than the last position in s.
Character positions in a string are indexed starting from zero.
The following code example demonstrates M:System.Char.GetUnicodeCategory(System.Char).

index is less than zero or greater than the last position in s.

summary.para: Indicates whether a Unicode character is categorized as a decimal digit.
Indicates whether the specified Unicode character is categorized as a decimal digit.

content.para: A Unicode character.

returnValue.para: true if c is a decimal digit; otherwise, false.

content.para: This method determines if a T:System.Char is a radix-10 digit. This contrasts with M:System.Char.IsNumber(System.Char) which determines if a Char is of any numeric Unicode category.
Valid digits are members of the following category in T:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory: DecimalDigitNumber.
The following code example demonstrates M:System.Char.IsDigit(System.Char).

The character position in s.

returnValue.para: true if the character at position index in s is an uppercase letter; otherwise, false.

content.para: s is null.
index is less than zero or greater than the last position in s.
Character positions in a string are indexed starting from zero.
Valid uppercase letters are members of the following category in T:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory: UppercaseLetter.

summary.para: Indicates whether a Unicode character is categorized as white space.
Indicates whether the specified Unicode character is categorized as white space.

content.para: A Unicode character.

returnValue.para: true if c is white space; otherwise, false.

content.para: White space characters are the following Unicode characters:

listItem.para: Members of the F:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory.SpaceSeparator category, which includes the SPACE character (U+0020).
Members of the F:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory.LineSeparator category, which consists solely of the LINE SEPARATOR character (U+2028).
Members of the F:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory.ParagraphSeparator category, which consists solely of the PARAGRAPH SEPARATOR character (U+2029).
The characters CHARACTER TABULATION (U+0009), LINE FEED (U+000A), LINE TABULATION (U+000B), FORM FEED (U+000C), CARRIAGE RETURN (U+000D), NEXT LINE (U+0085), and NO-BREAK SPACE (U+0000A0).

content.para: The following code example demonstrates M:System.Char.IsWhiteSpace(System.Char).

summary.para: Indicates whether a Unicode character is categorized as white space.
Indicates whether the character at the specified position in a specified string is categorized as white space.

content.para: A string.
The character position in s.

returnValue.para: true if the character at position index in s is white space; otherwise, false.

content.para: s is null.
index is less than zero or greater than the last position in s.
Character positions in a string are indexed starting from zero.
White space characters are the following Unicode characters:

listItem.para: Members of the F:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory.SpaceSeparator category, which includes the SPACE character (U+0020).
Members of the F:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory.LineSeparator category, which consists solely of the LINE SEPARATOR character (U+2028).
Members of the F:System.Globalization.UnicodeCategory.ParagraphSeparator category, which consists solely of the PARAGRAPH SEPARATOR character (U+2029).
The characters CHARACTER TABULATION (U+0009), LINE FEED (U+000A), LINE TABULATION (U+000B), FORM FEED (U+000C), CARRIAGE RETURN (U+000D), NEXT LINE (U+0085), and NO-BREAK SPACE (U+0000A0).

content.para: The following code example demonstrates M:System.Char.IsWhiteSpace(System.Char).

summary.para: Represents the largest possible value of a T:System.Char. This field is constant.

content.para: The value of this constant is hexadecimal 0xFFFF.

summary.para: Represents the smallest possible value of a T:System.Char. This field is constant.

content.para: The value of this constant is hexadecimal 0x00.

summary.para: Converts the value of the specified string to its equivalent Unicode character.

content.para: A string containing a single character or null.

returnValue.para: A Unicode character equivalent to the sole character in s.

content.para: s is null.
The length of s is not 1.
The following code example demonstrates M:System.Char.Parse(System.String).

summary.para: NoteThis conversion is not supported. Attempting to do so throws an T:System.InvalidCastException.

content.para: An T:System.IFormatProvider object. (Specify null because the provider parameter is ignored.)

returnValue.para: No value is returned.

content.para: This conversion is not supported.

content.para: An T:System.IFormatProvider object. (Specify null because the provider parameter is ignored.)

returnValue.para: The converted value of the current T:System.Char object.

returnValue.para: The value of the current T:System.Char object.

summary.para: NoteThis conversion is not supported. Attempting to do so throws an T:System.InvalidCastException.

returnValue.para: No value is returned.

content.para: This conversion is not supported.

content.para: An T:System.IFormatProvider object. (Specify null because the provider parameter is ignored.)

returnValue.para: The converted value of the current T:System.Char object.

summary.para: Converts value of the current T:System.Char object to a 64-bit signed integer.

content.para: An T:System.IFormatProvider object. (Specify null because the provider parameter is ignored.)

returnValue.para: The converted value of the current T:System.Char object.

summary.para: Converts the value of the current T:System.Char object to an object of the specified type using the specified T:System.IFormatProvider object.

content.para: A T:System.Type object.
An T:System.IFormatProvider object.

returnValue.para: An object of the specified type.

content.para: type is null.
The value of the current T:System.Char object cannot be converted to the type specified by the type parameter.

returnValue.para: The converted value of the current T:System.Char object.

summary.para: Converts the value of a Unicode character to its lowercase equivalent.

content.para: A Unicode character.

returnValue.para: The lowercase equivalent of c, or the unchanged value of c, if c is already lowercase or not alphabetic.

content.para: Casing rules are obtained from the current culture.
Use M:System.String.ToLower to convert a string to lowercase.
The following code example demonstrates M:System.Char.ToLower(System.Char,System.Globalization.CultureInfo).

summary.para: Converts the value of a Unicode character to its lowercase equivalent.
Converts the value of a specified Unicode character to its lowercase equivalent using specified culture-specific formatting information.

content.para: A Unicode character.
A T:System.Globalization.CultureInfo object that supplies culture-specific casing rules, or null.

returnValue.para: The lowercase equivalent of c, modified according to culture, or the unchanged value of c, if c is already lowercase or not alphabetic.

content.para: culture is null.
Use M:System.String.ToLower to convert a string to lowercase.
The following code example demonstrates M:System.Char.ToLower(System.Char,System.Globalization.CultureInfo).

summary.para: Converts the value of a Unicode character to its lowercase equivalent.
Converts the value of a Unicode character to its lowercase equivalent using the casing rules of the invariant culture.

content.para: A Unicode character.

returnValue.para: The lowercase equivalent of the c parameter, or the unchanged value of c, if c is already lowercase or not alphabetic.

content.para: If your application is unaffected by the current culture and depends on the case of a character changing in a predictable way, then use the M:System.Char.ToLowerInvariant(System.Char) method. The M:System.Char.ToLowerInvariant(System.Char) method is equivalent to ToLower(Char, CultureInfo.InvariantCulture).
Use M:System.String.ToLowerInvariant to convert a string to lowercase.

summary.para: Converts the value of this instance to its equivalent string representation.
Converts the value of this instance to its equivalent string representation.

returnValue.para: The string representation of the value of this instance.

content.para: The following code example demonstrates M:System.Char.ToString.

summary.para: Converts the value of this instance to its equivalent string representation.
Converts the specified Unicode character to its equivalent string representation.

content.para: A Unicode character.

returnValue.para: The string representation of the value of c.

content.para: The following code example demonstrates M:System.Char.ToString.

summary.para: Converts the value of this instance to its equivalent string representation using the specified culture-specific format information.

content.para: (Reserved) An T:System.IFormatProvider that supplies culture-specific formatting information.

returnValue.para: The string representation of the value of this instance as specified by provider.

content.para: The provider parameter is ignored; it does not participate in this operation.
The following code example demonstrates an overload of M:System.Char.ToString.

summary.para: Converts the value of a Unicode character to its uppercase equivalent.
Converts the value of a Unicode character to its uppercase equivalent.

content.para: A Unicode character.

returnValue.para: The uppercase equivalent of c, or the unchanged value of c, if c is already uppercase or not alphabetic.

content.para: Casing rules are obtained from the current culture.
Use M:System.String.ToUpper to convert a string to uppercase.

summary.para: Converts the value of a Unicode character to its uppercase equivalent.
Converts the value of a specified Unicode character to its uppercase equivalent using specified culture-specific formatting information.

content.para: A Unicode character.
A T:System.Globalization.CultureInfo object that supplies culture-specific casing rules, or null.

returnValue.para: The uppercase equivalent of c, modified according to culture, or the unchanged value of c, if c is already uppercase or not alphabetic.

content.para: culture is null.
Use M:System.String.ToUpper to convert a string to uppercase.

summary.para: Converts the value of a Unicode character to its uppercase equivalent using the casing rules of the invariant culture.

content.para: A Unicode character.

returnValue.para: The uppercase equivalent of the c parameter, or the unchanged value of c, if c is already uppercase or not alphabetic.

content.para: If your application is unaffected by the current culture and depends on the case of a character changing in a predictable way, use the M:System.Char.ToUpperInvariant(System.Char) method. The M:System.Char.ToUpperInvariant(System.Char) method is equivalent to ToUpper(Char, CultureInfo.InvariantCulture).
Use M:System.String.ToUpperInvariant to convert a string to uppercase.

summary.para: Converts the value of the specified string to its equivalent Unicode character. A return code indicates whether the conversion succeeded or failed.

content.para: A string containing a single character or null.

When this method returns, contains a Unicode character equivalent to the sole character in s, if the conversion succeeded, or an undefined value if the conversion failed. The conversion fails if the s parameter is null or the length of s is not 1. This parameter is passed uninitialized.

returnValue.para: true if the s parameter was converted successfully; otherwise, false.

content.para: The M:System.Char.TryParse(System.String,System.Char@) method is like the M:System.Char.Parse(System.String) method, except the M:System.Char.TryParse(System.String,System.Char@) method does not throw an exception if the conversion fails.

The following code example demonstrates overloads of the M:System.Char.TryParse(System.String,System.Char@) method for several base types, and the Overload:System.DateTime.TryParseExact method for the T:System.DateTime base type.
